awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Elucidating Molecular Level Interplay Between Catalysts and Electrolytes in Electrochemical Reduction of CO2
awd_abstract_narration:
The project addresses electrochemical reduction of the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide (ERCO2) - a critical step in sustainable strategies for generating fuels and commodity chemicals.  More efficient and cost-effective routes for ERCO2 are needed for technological viability.  In particular, interactions between the electrolyte and the electrocatalyst in ERCO2 cells are largely responsible for the overall performance of the system, yet are not well understood. The project addresses this need by employing a suite of advanced chemical characterization techniques to gain insight for the design of more effective polymer electrolytes and nanostructured catalysts. The project will also increase education and public awareness of the economic and environmental impact of electrochemical processes for converting CO2 to fuels and chemicals.

A combination of in-situ surface-specific spectroscopic, electrokinetic, and isotope labeling techniques will be employed to elucidate the mechanism of the electrode surface-mediated ECRCO2 and its interplay with cations and anions in the electrolyte at the molecular level. Bicarbonate, the most commonly used anion in ECRCO2, is proposed to enhance the reaction rate by increasing the effective CO2 concentration at the electrode surface via the dynamic CO2-bicarbonate equilibrium. Moreover, electrostatically bound cations could reduce the access of reactants to the surface via site blocking at negative electrode potentials. Correlation between the structure of organic cations and the site blocking effect will be established. Insights gained in these mechanistic studies will be used in the design of polymer electrolytes for future ECRCO2 devices. Further, design principles for nanostructured catalysts with minimum transport limitation will be extracted by developing an experimental method to measure the pH, and in turn CO2 concentration, within 10 nm from the electrode surface in-situ.  More broadly, special emphasis will be paid to attracting and retaining students from underrepresented groups in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) programs via a mobile device based software platform (the "GreenTech" app) to provide education and awareness of the need for sustainable and environmentally benign energy utilization.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Renewable electricity powered electrochemical reduction of CO2 (ECRCO2) is a promising and potentially sustainable platform to convert existing atmospheric CO2 to fuels and commodity chemicals. The scalability of electrochemical devices makes them ideal for converting CO2 from diffuse sources. The development of efficient ECRCO2 processes is hampered by the lack of solid understanding of the reaction pathway on the molecular level and the interaction between the electrode and the electrolyte, which could at least in part be blamed on the lack of experimental techniques to probe the electrochemical interface under reaction conditions. During the funded period, we employed and developed in-situ surface enhanced infrared and Raman spectroscopies to systematically investigate the surface speciation of Cu catalysts, the cation effect, and interfacial pH at conditions relevant to ECRCO2. Specifically, we demonstrated that multiple oxygen-containing species were present on Cu surfaces at reducing potentials, contrary to many previous reports, but they did not have strong correlations with rates and selectivities in the conversion of CO, a key reaction intermediate in the ECRCO2. We also showed that the interfacial electric field strength was not the sole decisive variable in the ECRCO2, which paved way to more detailed mechanistic understanding of electrocatalytic reactions in general. In addition, we provided convincing experimental evidence against the pH dependence in the conversion of CO, which has become as a key result in understanding the mechanism and identifying the rate determining step in the ECRCO2. In summary, the experimental techniques developed and mechanistic insights gained during the funding period of this project significantly advanced the mechanistic understanding of ECRCO2 and enhanced the ability of the community to elucidate electrocatalytic reactions in general.

 


Last Modified: 06/11/2022
Modified by: Bingjun Xu
